review_title: Good company, disconnect between local and HQ management
pros: The local management is fantastic, they're very flexible but are very knowledgeable and supportive. Despite it being the oilfield, they try to make reasonable, achievable goals for everyone.
cons:
Honestly, sometimes big companies make decisions that make sense to managers that are very removed from the people and customers of a business unit, but it might be nice to see more deference given to local management when times get tough. Don't forget, oilfield hours, so 24/7/365.25, if you aren't prepared for that, it might be best to look at a different industry.
Advice to Management
Local management: stay the course and endure. We know you all have bills to pay just like we do.
HQ management: don't forget the little people, they aren't just numbers. And listen to the local management team. Also, don't take away the few perks the job has (such as vehicle allowance). It makes the entire team embittered to get worked harder for less money. I know that historically it has been relatively easy to recruit talent because the oilfield pays better, but no one likes getting mistreated. The 'your pay can be changed at anytime' is one of those problems that will haunt the entire oilfield in the near future. Anyway, if the shoe were on the other foot regarding things like vehicle allowance, you'd probably have a lot to say about it. Also, perhaps it might be helpful that when HQ management announces core values, it might be good to solicit and utilize "commoner employee" feedback about how to actually apply those core values when times get tough. As what was once told to me, it's very easy to run an oil company at $100/BBL, but the crap hits the fan when oil hits $20/BBL. That's when you'll really see those core values in action, or otherwise.

review_title: 1.3 Yrs @ Baker Hughes - Pune - Former GE Oil & Gas
pros:
1. Salary is huge as per industry standard.
2. Not very sure about hike as i didin't receive it as was only into 6 months during the increment cycle.
3.Nice technologies to work with and brilliant people.

This is my second update. Have given the first one after 6 months of joining as well.
cons:
1. Work pressure in BH Pune is huge. I have been working for 10+ hrs almost everyday since Feb 2020. With incoming covid and WFH it has crossed 14+ hrs for 1-2 days weekly as well. (And no comp-offs or overhead salary for extra hours spent.)

2. Agile methodology is followed while giving updates. So updates are crisp, and everyone gets to know which work is done/pending. However, due to dependency on other teams for few works, tasks gets stuck on out name for more days. Hence causing problems which FMs/TPMs don't try to understand even on explaining.

3. Most of the people in here are quite experienced with 10+ years of experience. As such most of them are having a galla time with WFH, avoiding work and putting pressure of lesser experienced folks while enjoying time with family.

4. FMs have no idea whatsoever about who is working on what/how. As such performance measurement is given by other people on your team. As such blame game is quite common otherwise they wont have a decent enough review. TLs are TLs in name only. (at least the one i have been working with). Never seen doing something with the leadership skills allotted for leading. It really hurts when you dont get a decent review even after working 10-14+ hrs for over 9 months continuously.
Advice to Management
1. FMs needs to know how/when someone is performing. Our reviews shouldnt be dependent on other people's reviewes about us. This creates a rift within the same team we are working with.

2. Acknowledgement and appreciation is required for hard work. Didint see that anywhere. Also, just a blank appreciation mail won't do. We are working as an employee for the base pay. An monetary/other form of compensation should follow through.

3. WFH doesn't mean that we should be working 14+ hrs. Your TPMs don't get that. They need only updates. I have been getting calls at 10P.M. to do stuff and asking about updates on it the next day at 11 A.M. This is impossible to do. We aren't GODs.

4.If you want to retain fresh employees and not just the legacy GE Oil & Gas employees better take heed of whats happening within the organization as i have seen quite a few of brightest minds leave the organization and i too am planning to do so within a year in case I don't notice any change within the organization.
The GE tag name makes it quite easy to switch jobs in software/core industries. 

5.Why 3 yr is required for any promotion? There shouldn't be any such thing. I dont see a very bright career ahead with all the above, Moreover Oil & Gas industry is quite cynical and everyone is frightened with what happened in kochi. Better take control of you might lose a huge chunk of your workforce as soon as covid ends. BH has a pretty bad reputation now in the job market after sacking 25% workforce from kochi. So would be pretty tough to get newer employees.
